thread.title: MPs warn Theresa May her current Brexit plans won't save the car industry

author: Jonathan Walker
title: MPs warn Theresa May her current Brexit plans won't save the car industry
text:
MPs warn Theresa May her current Brexit plans won't save the car industry UK must stick with EU rules after Brexit to protect manufacturing jobs, say MPs Share Prime Minister Theresa May speaks during Prime Minister's Questions in the House of Commons, London (Image: PA) Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
MPs have warned the UK must abandon its Brexit plans and sign up to EU institutions and rules if it hopes to save major car manufacturers.
The House of Commons Brexit Committee urged the Government to consider staying in the EU single market and the customs union, an arrangement currently rejected by the Government.
It follows warnings from carmakers such as Nissan that they must be able to continue importing car parts from EU countries without restrictions, in order to protect UK jobs.
That’s because they use a manufacturing process known as “just in time”, in which parts arrive at the factory as they are needed. Jaguar cars on the production line at Jaguar Castle Bromwich factory, Birmingham (Image: Birmingham Post and Mail)
If components are delayed because of border checks then manufacturing is likely to grind to a halt.
In a sign of the dangers facing the car industry, Midlands-based Jaguar Land Rover, which also operates a “just in time” system, has announced it’s introducing a three-day-week at one of its plants, due partly to Brexit uncertainty. Read More
The Commons Brexit Committee warned that the European Union’s proposed trade agreement with the UK, which is based on the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) signed between the EU and Canada, would not protect manufacturers. Workers at Nissan (Image: PA)
It said: “The Commission is proposing a CETA-style Free Trade Agreement, but we note that this would not, on its own, ensure the type of friction-free trade that many companies with just-in-time supply chains need.”
And MPs said the UK Government’s proposals, known as the Chequers agreement, are doomed to failure because the EU will not agree to them.
MPs said one solution would be to stay in the European Economic Area. This means staying in the EU’s single market and the Customs Union, allowing products to be moved without restriction between the EU and the UK. The EU flag and a Union Jack (Image: PA)
Some Brexiteers oppose this option because it would mean the UK continued to obey some EU rules.
The Committee said another option would be to form a Customs Union with the EU - combined with “continued alignment on relevant EU rules”, which once again would mean the UK continues to obey some rules made in Brussels. Read More Home Office urged to help Operation Sanctuary sex abuse victims put their lives back together
Urging the Government to think again, the MPs warned: “The European Commission has now indicated that the Chequers proposals for a Facilitated Customs Arrangement and a common rulebook are not viable and if this remains the position then the Government will need to adapt its approach to the future EU-UK economic relationship.”
But the report by backbench MPs provoked a row even before it was published, with three hardline Brexiteers on the Committee refusing to sign up to it.
They included Tories Jacob Rees-Mogg and Andrea Jenkyns, and DUP MP Sammy Wilson.
Minutes from the Committee show that Mr Rees-Mogg, Ms Jenkyns and Mr Wilson voted against publishing the report, but they were overruled by 13 MPs on the committee who voted to release it. Like us on Facebook
